text: In a normal (Gaussian) distribution, approximately what percentage of observations fall within ±1 standard deviation (SD) from the mean?
explanation:
Normal distribution describes a symmetrical bell‑shaped curve in which data are evenly distributed about the mean, median, and mode (all equal). Each standard deviation (SD) represents a fixed interval from the mean. In a perfectly normal distribution:

• ≈ 68% of values lie within ± 1 SD.
• ≈ 95% within ± 2 SD.
• ≈ 99.7% within ± 3 SD.

This pattern is known as the empirical rule (68‑95‑99.7 rule).

High‑yield recap:
✅ 68% → ±1 SD ✅ 95% → ±2 SD ✅ 99.7% → ±3 SD.

text: Approximately what percentage of observations lie outside ±2 SD from the mean in a normal distribution?
explanation:
If 95% of data lie within ± 2 SD, the remaining 5% fall outside — 2.5% below –2 SD and 2.5% above +2 SD.

Values beyond ± 2 SD are considered statistically unusual; those beyond ± 3 SD (≈ 0.3%) are outliers.

High‑yield recap:
✅ ± 1 SD → 68% inside, 32% outside.
✅ ± 2 SD → 95% inside, 5% outside.
✅ ± 3 SD → 99.7% inside, 0.3% outside.

text: In a dataset of dental exam scores with a mean of 70 and a standard deviation of 10, approximately what range contains 95% of all scores if the data are normally distributed?
explanation:
In a normal distribution, 95% of data lie within ± 2 SD. Thus, 70 ± (2 × 10) = 50 to 90.

This interval contains nearly all observations, while only ≈ 5% fall outside (≈ 2.5% on each tail).

text: A researcher notes that a data set has a mean = 50 and median = 40. What can be inferred about the shape of its distribution?
explanation:
When the mean > median > mode, the distribution is positively (right) skewed — a long right‑hand tail caused by a few large values.

Conversely, mean < median < mode → negative (left) skew. Normal distribution occurs when all three are equal.

High‑yield recap:
✅ Mean > Median → Right skew.
✅ Mean < Median → Left skew.
✅ Mean = Median = Mode → Normal curve.

text: Which of the following statistical tests compares the means of two independent groups to determine if they differ significantly?
explanation:
The Student’s t-test (independent t-test) compares the means between two independent, unrelated samples — for example, comparing the mean blood pressure of males vs females.

It determines whether the difference between two group means is statistically significant, assuming normally distributed data and equal variances.

- Paired t-test: used for related samples (same subjects before & after treatment).
- ANOVA: compares ≥ 3 groups.
- Chi-square: compares categorical frequencies, not means.

text: A researcher measures probing depths before and after periodontal therapy in the same group of patients. Which statistical test should be used?
explanation:
The Paired t-test compares two related means — when the same subjects are tested twice (pre- vs post-intervention). It accounts for intra-subject correlation, isolating the treatment effect.

Example: mean CAL before vs after scaling and root planing.
It differs from the independent t-test because both data sets come from the same sample population.

text: Which of the following tests is most appropriate when comparing the means of three or more independent groups?
explanation:
ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) compares means across three or more groups to determine if at least one mean differs significantly. It extends the t-test concept to multiple groups while controlling the overall Type I error rate.

If ANOVA shows a significant result, post-hoc tests (e.g., Tukey’s HSD) identify which specific groups differ.

- One-way ANOVA: one independent variable.
- Two-way ANOVA: two independent variables (e.g., treatment × gender).

text: Which of the following tests is best used to determine if there is a significant association between two categorical variables (e.g., smoking status and presence of periodontitis)?
explanation:
The Chi-square (χ²) test assesses whether an observed frequency distribution differs from what is expected by chance — it tests for associations between categorical variables.

It is used on nominal data (counts or percentages), not continuous data like means or standard deviations.

Example: frequency of periodontitis among smokers vs non-smokers.
A significant χ² value → association exists between variables, but it does not indicate direction or strength.
